commits.message: Show web page title in tab when browsing
commits.body:
The tab once showed "web google.com"—
A name quite bland, devoid of chrome.
Now when you surf, the title gleams,
With "Google Search" or Netflix streams.
Close the view? It snaps right back,
The terminal reclaims its track.

Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
commits.author: Ryan X. Charles

commits.body:
A browser tab once sat forlorn,
Its icon blank since it was born.
Now pixels form a tiny face—
TermSurf has claimed its proper place.

Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
commits.author: Ryan X. Charles

commits.body:
From hallucipedia the browser roamed,
Now termsurf.com is where it's homed.

Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
commits.author: Ryan X. Charles

commits.body:
The build artifacts cried,
"Track us not!" So we complied.
commits.author: Ryan X. Charles

commits.message: Deploy to Fly.io with Bun SSR
commits.body:
The server once spoke JavaScript,
A compiled tongue, quite restrictive.
Now TypeScript runs free,
As Bun meant it to be—
No build step! How linguistically festive!

Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
commits.author: Ryan X. Charles

commits.message: Add expandable commit details with GitHub links
commits.body:
Click a commit and watch it grow,
Its hidden message starts to show.
A chevron turns, the body's there,
With GitHub links for those who care.
No message? We'll say so with grace—
An italic note takes its place.

Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
commits.author: Ryan X. Charles

commits.message: Add GitPoet skill for poetic commits
commits.body:
A commit message, plain and dry?
That simply will not do, says I!
Now verses flow with every push,
Through limericks, haiku, and such—
Your git log makes the readers cry (with joy).

Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
commits.author: Ryan X. Charles

commits.message: Port upstream Ghostty macOS app changes to termsurf-macos
commits.body:
Changes ported from macos/ to termsurf-macos/:

- SplitTree.swift: Rename methods to verb-ed form (insert→inserting,
  remove→removing, replace→replacing, equalize→equalized, resize→resizing)
- BaseTerminalController.swift: Update SplitTree calls, make
  replaceSurfaceTree internal, add selectionForFind/scrollToSelection
  actions, fix applyTitleToWindow for bell indicator
- TerminalController.swift: Add replaceSurfaceTree override for empty
  tree handling
- Ghostty.App.swift: Fix search state to update needle and always post
  focus notification
- Ghostty.Input.swift: Add BindingFlags struct
- Ghostty.Surface.swift: Add keyIsBinding methods returning flags
- SurfaceDragSource.swift: Add acceptsFirstMouse/mouseDown overrides to
  fix window drag bug (#10110)
- SurfaceView.swift: Fix search focus race condition with
  DispatchQueue.main.async, add context property to SurfaceConfiguration
- SurfaceView_AppKit.swift: Refactor performKeyEquivalent to use new
  binding flags API and integrate with system menu, add find actions
- DraggableWindowView.swift: Deleted (removed upstream)

Note: Menu items for "Use Selection for Find" and "Jump to Selection"
need to be added manually in Xcode (MainMenu.xib + AppDelegate outlets).

Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
commits.author: Ryan X. Charles

commits.message: Fix build after upstream merge: update API calls
commits.body:

- ghostty_surface_key_is_binding now requires flags output parameter

Our changes preserved:
- src/cli/web.zig (web command)

commits.message: Fix memory leak when pruning scrollback with non-standard pages (#10251)
commits.body:
This _finally_ resolves #9962 (and the myriad of dupes). 

The core issue was that when a non-standard size page is reused as part
of our scrollback pruning, it was resized to be standard size, which
caused our future frees to believe it was pooled and not call `munmap`
properly.

The solution I chose was to never reuse non-standard sized pages. If
during scrollback pruning we detect a non-standard page, we destroy it
and re-alloc. This frees the old memory and reuses pool memory for the
new page.

As part of this, I also introduced a custom page allocator that uses
macOS's mach kernel virtual memory tagging feature to specifically tag
our PageList memory. I was able to use this in conjunction with
Instruments and `footprint` to verify that our PageList memory was
previously not freed and is now successfully freed.

**No AI was used in my work here.** AI was used by others in their
analysis of this issue that I used the results of to help guide me and
give me other things to consider, but the ultimate understanding and fix
was all done via my own meat sticks.

## Detailed Explainer

Ghostty uses a memory pool of fixed-size `mmap`-ed pages to serve as the
backing memory for our terminal. If the terminal requires a non-standard
(larger) amount of memory due to an abundance of emoji, styles,
hyperlinks, etc. then we allocate non-pooled pages directly with `mmap`.
When freeing our pages, if it is `<= standard size` we just put it back
into the memory pool. If it is larger, we `munmap` it.

This explains and defines both a _standard_ and therefore _non-standard_
page.

Ghostty also has the concept of a "scrollback limit" (exposed to the
user via the `scrollback-limit` config). This caps the size of our
scrollback or history. When we reach this limit, we have a trick that we
do: to avoid allocation, we reuse the oldest page in the history.

Unfortunately, as part of this process, we were resizing the underlying
memory to be standard size again. This was causing our future frees to
believe this was pooled memory, and never unmap it. This was the main
source of the leak.

## Thanks

Big shout out to @grishy for being the person that finally got me a
reproduction so I could analyze the issue for myself. His own analysis
got to the same conclusion as me but thanks to the reproduction I was
able to verify both our understandings independently.
commits.author: Mitchell Hashimoto

commits.author: Mitchell Hashimoto

commits.body:
These workflows were inherited from the Ghostty fork and don't work for
TermSurf because they:
- Require Ghostty-specific runners (namespace-profile-ghostty-*)
- Reference secrets we don't have (Cachix, R2, Sentry, Apple signing)
- Have repository conditions that skip for non-ghostty-org repos

This was causing failure notification emails on every push/tag.

Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
